intro: Stillingia sanguinolenta var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf stinging beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, characterized by its distinctive, branched stems and alternate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are followed by red, berry-like fruits containing seeds. Its leaves and stems are covered in fine hairs and can cause skin irritation upon contact. This variant is often found in moist, wooded areas and is sometimes used in traditional herbal medicine.
